DIGEST OF  INTRODUCED B ILL
Citations Affected:  IC 5-10-8-27; IC 12-7-2-34; IC 12-8-15;
IC 12-15-5-7.5; IC 12-23-16-2; IC 16-18-2; IC 16-41-45; IC 22-9;
IC 27-8; IC 27-13-7.
Synopsis:  Pregnancy and childbirth matters. Sets forth requirements
for screening for preeclampsia using biomarker testing. Requires
coverage for biomarker testing for preeclampsia under a state employee
health plan, the Medicaid program, a policy of accident and sickness
insurance, and a health maintenance organization contract. Establishes
the trauma informed care commission (commission). Requires the
division of mental health and addiction to develop and implement a
program for pregnant women and children with a substance use
disorder. Prohibits an employer from discriminating against an
employee who has a condition related to pregnancy or childbirth.
Requires an employer to provide reasonable employment
accommodations for an employee who has a condition related to
pregnancy or childbirth. Requires the civil rights commission to
investigate and attempt to resolve complaints relating to pregnancy and
childbirth discrimination. Repeals a chapter regarding pregnancy and
childbirth accommodation. Requires an insurer that issues a policy of
accident and sickness insurance or a health maintenance organization
to make available coverage for contraception without out-of-pocket
costs to women otherwise covered by health plans sponsored by
employers or institutions of higher education that are objecting
organizations and do not invoke an optional accommodation under
federal law.
Effective:  July 1, 2025.
Hunley,  Yoder,  Jackson L

35 Chapter 45. Preeclampsia Biomarker Testing
36 Sec. 1. (a) As used in this chapter, "biomarker" means a
37 characteristic that is objectively measured and evaluated as an
38 indicator of normal biological processes, pathogenic processes, or
39 pharmacologic responses to a specific therapeutic intervention. 
40 (b) The term includes the following:
41 (1) Gene mutations.
42 (2) Protein expression.
2025 IN 521—LS 7144/DI 141


--- Page 12 ---
11
1 (3) Known gene-drug interactions for medications.
2 (4) Characteristics of genes.
3 Sec. 2. (a) As used in this chapter, "biomarker testing" means
4 the analysis of a patient's tissue, blood, or other biospecimen for
5 the presence of a biomarker using a federal Food and Drug
6 Administration approved method of analysis.
7 (b) The term includes the following:
8 (1) Single-analyte tests.
9 (2) Multiplex panel tests.
10 (3) Whole genome sequencing.
11 (4) Protein expression.
12 (5) Whole exome.
13 (6) Whole transcriptome.
14 Sec. 3. As used in this chapter, "consensus statements" means
15 statements that are:
16 (1) developed by an independent, multi-disciplinary panel of
17 experts:
18 (A) utilizing a transparent methodology and reporting
19 structure; and
20 (B) with a conflict of interest policy;
21 (2) aimed at specific clinical circumstances; and
22 (3) based on the best available evidence for the purpose of
23 optimizing the outcomes of clinical care.
24 Sec. 4. As used in this chapter, "nationally recognized clinical
25 practice guidelines" means evidence based clinical practice
26 guidelines that:
27 (1) are developed by independent organizations or medical
28 professional societies:
29 (A) utilizing a transparent methodology and reporting
30 structure; and
31 (B) with a conflict of interest policy;
32 (2) establish standards of care informed by:
33 (A) a systematic review of evidence; and
34 (B) an assessment of the benefits and risks of alternative
35 care options; and
36 (3) include recommendations intended to optimize patient
37 care.

39 using biomarker testing if the biomarker testing is ordered by the
40 attending physician in accordance with this chapter.

5 Chapter 40. Contraception Coverage

12 accident and sickness insurance (as defined in IC 27-8-5-1) entered
13 into or renewed after June 30, 2025.

15 insurance" has the meaning set forth in IC 27-8-5-1.
16 Sec. 4. An insurer that issues a policy of accident and sickness
17 insurance shall make available coverage for contraception:
18 (1) for a wom an who is covered under a health plan that is
19 established or maintained by a plan sponsor that:
20 (A) is a nongovernmental employer or institution of higher
21 education that is an objecting organization under 45 CFR
22 147.132 or 45 CFR 147.133; and
23 (B) does not invoke an optional accommodation under 45
24 CFR 147.131; and
25 (2) without any applicable copayment, coinsurance,
26 deductible, or other out-of-pocket cost.
27 Sec. 5. A plan sponsor described in section 4(1) of this chapter
28 shall provide to an individual who is or will be covered under a
29 health plan described in section 4(1) of this chapter written notice
30 specifying the contraception for which coverage is not provided

33 in 45 CFR 147.132(a)(2) or 45 CFR 147.133(a)(2).

35 under the health plan.

38 to the coverage required by section 4 of this chapter by:
